body: Wilbur L. Woods, the director of the Brooklyn Office of the Department of City Planning, has worked in Brooklyn since 1977. In an interview he discussed the city's efforts to encourage development of city-owned sites in Brooklyn. Q. Has the city been successful in persuading companies to move their back- office space to Brooklyn? A. Not to any
title: Q & A WITH BROOKLYN'S CHIEF PLANNER; WILBUR L. WOODS TOUTS ADVANTAGES OF BOUROGH SITES

body: Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx have joined an economic recovery in New York City that until last year was limited largely to Manhattan, according to a Federal report released yesterday. The number of jobs in all five boroughs has increased for the first time since the city began to recover in 1977 from the severe recession earlier in
title: SURGE IN JOBS REPORTED IN ALL 5 CITY BOROUGHS

body: Shaker Country Tour , sponsored by Fraunces Tavern Museum, 212-425- 1778. This trip to the Shaker Museum in Old Chatham, N.Y., and Hancock Shaker Village near Pittsfield, Mass., will be next Thursday from 8 A.M. to about 7 P.M. It will include a visit to a cabinetmaker's workshop, a small chair factory, a blacksmith's shop, textile weaving shops
title: CALENDAR: A BUS TOUR TO SHAKER COUNTRY

body: When they added up the voting machine totals, Jim Brennan led Louise Finney by four votes in the Democratic primary in the 51st Assembly District in Brooklyn. When they added in the absentee and paper ballots, Mrs. Finney led Mr. Brennan by two votes. But when they discovered that about 250 votes out of more than 6,500 cast were invalid in the
title: CANDIDATES FOR ASSEMBLY SEAT FACE A PRIMARY VOTE-AGAIN

body: A commission formed by Mayor Koch, in a final report that strengthened its preliminary recommendations, has urged that New York City spend tens of millions of additional dollars each year to create low- and moderate-income housing. The panel, called the Development Commitments Study Commission, reiterated a proposal made in an earlier working
title: CITY URGED TO ALLOT 'TENS OF MILLIONS' MORE TO HOUSING

body: Nine city-owned buildings will soon become living and work space for artists, Mayor Koch said yesterday. Groups of artists will buy the buildings for as little as $1, and in all but one case will rehabilitate them with their own money into moderately priced rental or cooperative units, the Mayor said at a City Hall news conference. The Commissioner
title: THE CITY; City Will SellHousing to Artists

body: Festa Italiana, Carmine Street at Avenue of the Americas. Today, from 6 P.M., tomorrow and Sunday from noon. Singers, including the Italian Folk Ensemble; dancers, ethnic food. Sponsored by Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Pompeii. Information: 989- 6805. Street Fair , 126th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues. Today, 6 to 9 P.M.;
title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend

body: Two children died in a fire that swept the top floor of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, the Fire Department reported. Three other people were injured. A Fire Department spokesman, Samuel Lopez, said the blaze broke out at about 3 P.M. in the top floor of a four-story brick building at 272 45th Street, near Third Avenue, in the Sunset Park
title: THE CITY ; ; 2 Children Die In Brooklyn Fire

body: A Brooklyn school district did not effectively use the 1,000 teachers in its 25 elementary and junior high schools, according to a state audit released yesterday. The audit, an eight-month study in 1981-82 by the State Comptroller's office, criticized Community School District 15, which had an enrollment of 20,500 students at the time. ''For the
title: THE CITY; School District 15 Criticized by State

body: More police officers will be assigned to deal with such ''quality of life'' crimes as prostitution, gambling, drug dealing and vandalism under a reorganization plan announced yesterday by the Police Department. The goal, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said at a news conference at City Hall, is to put more emphasis on community-based crime
title: CITY CRACKS DOWN ON STREET CRIMES

body: A man estranged from his wife hanged their two children yesterday while seeing them on visitation rights, and then hanged himself, the police said last night. The bodies were discovered at the man's apartment in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn by his wife, who went there after the children were not returned on time. The man, Antonio Centeno, 28
title: THE CITY; Man Said to Kill Himself and Kin

body: THERE may be no better place to observe the ebb and flow of industrial real estate in Brooklyn than at Bush Terminal, the waterfront complex that is said to be the world's largest multitenant industrial facility. This year, measured by tenant expansions, the tide appears to be flowing rather than ebbing. Yet there is no shortage of available space.
title: BUSH TERMINAL'S TENANTS ARE TAKING ON MORE SPACE

body: Standing among empty building shells in Queens and later beneath a towering cargo crane on the Brooklyn waterfront, Mayor Koch yesterday reminded people outside Manhattan that in these two projects his administration had assembled $66 million in public money for industrial and maritime development. On what he called ''a very special day,'' the
title: KOCH LEADS 2-STOP ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT TOUR

body: Subway Trains Kill 2 In Separate Incidents Two women, one of whom was apparently blind, were struck and killed by subway trains yesterday in separate incidents in Queens and Brooklyn, authorities said. The first death occurred at 6:20 A.M., when a woman who appeared to be in her 50's jumped in front of a southbound F train as it entered the
title: No Headline

body: Most of New York State's 285 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be chosen in today's Presidential primary. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Erie Counties. They will be open from noon until 9 P.M. elsewhere in the state. The Rev. Jesse
title: NEW YORKERS TO VOTE TODAY IN PRIMARY; JACKSON

body: THE nonprofit community development corporation has become one of the lasting institutional legacies of the turmoil of the 1960's in older American cities. The early model of the species was the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in Brooklyn. Now there are thousands around the country, greatly varying in effectiveness and in levels of
title: NONPROFIT REALTY GROUPS GETTING MORE PRIVATE HELP

body: A 22-year-old police officer has been found not guilty of assaulting and harassing a Brooklyn minister he arrested last summer in Times Square. A Manhattan Criminal Court jury Thursday acquitted the officer - Thomas Hill of Levittown, L.I., who is assigned to the Midtown South Precinct. Mary deBourbon of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office
title: THE CITY; Officer Acquitted Of Assault Charge

body: A $10 million loan program to help stimulate housing and commercial development in distressed urban areas was announced yesterday by the BankAmerica Foundation, a philanthropic organization set up by the Bank of America for charitable giving. The new program, called the BankAmerica Foundation Neighborhood Partnership, should be a ''major step
title: BANKAMERICA TO AID URBAN REGROWTH WORK

body: In a fit of delight, Carmen Fuentes kissed the wall of her apartment building. ''I'd rather kiss your feet,'' she told Dominick Cordi and Sol Riess, city inspectors bearing thermometers who had come to check the heat in her Brooklyn apartment building yesterday. ''Thank the Lord you've come.'' The men were part of a special team of 12 inspectors
title: CITY SHELTERS THOUSANDS AS COLD SNAP LINGERS

body: DAISY EDMONDSON and Stewart Alter, both magazine editors, left their small Greenwich Village apartment eight months ago because they had just had a baby and, what's more, their landlord had doubled the rent. After ''systematically'' canvassing neighborhoods just outside Manhattan for an affordable house to their liking, the couple finally bought a
title: RESALE-HOME PRICES: UP AND RISING
